content: Astrology Reminds Me I Exist The world tells me my decisions are governed by my body. My horoscope tells me otherwise. Danielle Morgan Blocked Unblock Follow Following Mar 6 Illustration: Danielle Morgan I can divide almost all my past relationships into two distinct parts: before I’ve told my partners about my affinity for astrology and after. The two parts are nearly indistinguishable from the outside but palpable from the inside. I remember one moment when I told a guy I’d been seeing for about three months that I liked reading my horoscope. He was cooking me dinner and he’d just popped a stray red pepper into his mouth. His jaw stopped moving, and I imagined the pepper pieces sitting slackly and half-chewed on his tongue. When he resumed chewing, I knew I’d been put into the “women who believe in astrology” category in his brain. At least I was in good company. “Ya, that makes sense,” he said and went back to chopping. We never talked about it again. I looked around my ex-boyfriend’s apartment and studied all the things he’d placed so carefully on shelves and in cupboards. We all use our surroundings (either consciously or unconsciously) to give the world hints about our interests and identities. We take these hints and make inferences about the people around us. Personally, I assume my simple, dark wardrobe and keen interest in melancholy playlists suggests I am slightly cold but clever. My collection of strangely shaped plants probably signals my distaste for uniformity, or possibly a looming instability. The mismatched mugs in the cupboard above my sink give a glimpse of sentimentality that is largely missing from the rest of my home. In general, women’s decisions are rarely portrayed as acts of free will at all. While these are relatively unconscious and frivolous externalizations of my personality, my bookshelf was always a carefully curated, purposeful manifestation of my deepest self and fundamental desires. Before I unceremoniously sold all my books and moved to another country, I would obsessively sort through the shelves, deciding which books should sit at eye level, what each one said about me, and which ones best encapsulated my view of this complicated world. My obsession with arranging my own bookshelf made it impossible for me to stop myself from scanning for clues on others’ shelves. This particular ex-boyfriend had a stack of boating magazines on his top shelf, and he’d placed Margaret Atwood, Ray Bradbury, and Philip K. Dick at eye level. This assortment made me wonder if he’d ever read Octavia E. Butler, and I made a mental note to ask him about it. Earlier in the week, he’d told me he wanted to be a stay-at-home dad, so I looked at the books on his bottom shelf and wondered if one day he’d read his Calvin and Hobbes comics and Pippi Longstocking books to his child. The manual for his stove sat horizontally on the top shelf, and his English degree lay limply over top of it. To be honest, I can’t remember a lot about this man, but I remember his bookshelf clearly. It stirred up in me all the questions and inquisitiveness I’d been trying to get my own bookshelf to bring about in others. While I scanned the shelves, I replayed all the times the men I’ve dated have nodded at my bookshelf and said, “ya, that makes sense.” While it’s never said with disdain or dismissal, it seems that no matter how I arrange my bookshelf or what I put on it, it always validates preformed predictions. Even when my interests are genuinely admired and given ample attention, they’re still treated like a series of unchangeable inevitabilities. While admiring my collection of Hemingway short stories, a man once said, “Ah, of course you fell for a badass like that.” While I am repulsed by the idea that someone would assume I select reading material based on my physical attraction to the author, the idea that some uncontrollable force drew me to a particular interest is more troublesome to me. Behind every admiring remark about my interests, there seems to be an assumption that I simply “fell” into them. My propensity to read my horoscope has always been met with a uniquely adamant and frantic assumption that I must have been unconsciously attracted to it. The men I’ve dated usually physically move away from me, and they often can’t think of a way to move the conversation forward after I’ve mentioned my star sign (and they nearly shut down if I mention my moon sign). While I can maybe understand their initial skepticism and surprise, it bothers me that almost none of them inquire about the reasoning behind my interest in astrology. It’s as though they don’t consider it something I decided at all. I mean, how could the otherwise intelligent and savvy woman in front of them believe in something as silly and ridiculous as star alignment? In general, women’s decisions are rarely portrayed as acts of free will. More often, they are considered predetermined by their bodies. My ex-boyfriend’s eventual decision to be a stay-at-home dad and read his child Pippi Longstocking might be unfairly viewed by some as an “unmanly” choice, and while he might face harmful backlash for it, at least it will be considered his own decision. But if I were to make the same choice, it likely wouldn’t be considered a decision at all. A woman’s desire to have children and/or to care for them isn’t really viewed as an active choice or a result of societal pressures. More often, it’s seen as an overwhelming biological urge that comes from deep within her body and cannot be quelled. Similarly, if my ex-boyfriend decided to work instead of staying home with his child, it wouldn’t be seen as a diversion from his body’s natural impulses like it would if I decided to work. At its core, the decision to carry or care for another human being is not seen as my own but rather my body’s. Men’s bodies are rarely considered to be the cause of anything. Instead, we see external circumstances as impacting their decisions. My decision to major in English and pursue a career in art is often met with boredom and shrugs, whereas my history in prototyping technologies is met with confusion. It’s assumed that I chose the humanities and art not because of my unique abilities with words or drawing but because my brain is physically wired for artistic, emotional work. Intelligent articles about women in science or technology are met with links to articles that claim women’s brains are not built to take on mathematical or spatial work. I can guarantee it was rarely suggested that my ex-boyfriend’s brain was physically unprepared to understand complex emotional subtext in contemporary fiction. My brain, however, appears to be destined for it. I would never suggest that men do not face criticism for choosing certain kinds of work or interests. I’ve seen men torn apart by their fathers or rude acquaintances who suggest they’ve made silly choices or that their social circumstances must have led them down such a ridiculous path when they could have been doctors or architects. No one, however, suggests that the male brain or body is physically incapable of pursuing any interest or decision. Men’s bodies are rarely considered to be the cause of anything. Instead, it is external circumstances that impact their decisions. While blaming or crediting societal circumstances for a person’s well-considered decisions isn’t always great, at least it’s somewhat escapable. If I wanted to escape assumptions about my decisions and interests, it appears I would have to physically crawl out of my own body. T his unconscious (and occasionally conscious) treatment of my body as some sort of prophetic machine honestly sounds more ludicrous than astrology’s predictions. Astrology is no less ridiculous or scientifically inaccurate than the idea that the female body somehow determines future decisions, reactions, and interests. Yet we seem to perpetuate this latter idea without hesitation. We’re all navigating the world looking for clues about who we are, who the people in our lives are, and how our lives are going to turn out. I believe that reading horoscopes and comparing astrological charts is a healthier way to make sense of the world than building false stereotypes and treating people like unconscious agents in their own lives. I don’t believe in astrology the way I wish I did. I don’t believe the sun determines my personality or the planets determine my mood. I wish I was that witchy, and I will continue to be in awe of people who are. After scrolling through thousands of articles that subtly or directly suggest that my body’s physical structure determines how I exist in the world, however, I find the deepest level of joy and comfort in subscribing to the idea that it’s actually the universe’s physical alignment that affects how I exist in the world. According to astrology, my decisions, interests, and reactions are directly affected by external circumstances. It doesn’t matter what body I inhabit. If it’s Pisces season and I’m born at the end of February, I’m going to be intolerably moody, intuitive, and cry a lot. I love astrological explanations of my personality. I love comparing my chart to the people around me. My horoscope acts as a daily reminder that despite everything in society telling me otherwise, the world and the people in it do affect me. In a subtle and mythical but wildly important way, astrology reminds me I exist.
title_html: Astrology Reminds Me I Exist

Astrology Reminds Me I Exist

The world tells me my decisions are governed by my body. My horoscope tells me otherwise.

Danielle Morgan
Mar 6

I can divide almost all my past relationships into two distinct parts: before I’ve told my partners about my affinity for astrology and after. The two parts are nearly indistinguishable from the outside but palpable from the inside.

I remember one moment when I told a guy I’d been seeing for about three months that I liked reading my horoscope. He was cooking me dinner and he’d just popped a stray red pepper into his mouth. His jaw stopped moving, and I imagined the pepper pieces sitting slackly and half-chewed on his tongue. When he resumed chewing, I knew I’d been put into the “women who believe in astrology” category in his brain. At least I was in good company.

“Ya, that makes sense,” he said and went back to chopping. We never talked about it again.

I looked around my ex-boyfriend’s apartment and studied all the things he’d placed so carefully on shelves and in cupboards. We all use our surroundings (either consciously or unconsciously) to give the world hints about our interests and identities. We take these hints and make inferences about the people around us.

Personally, I assume my simple, dark wardrobe and keen interest in melancholy playlists suggests I am slightly cold but clever. My collection of strangely shaped plants probably signals my distaste for uniformity, or possibly a looming instability. The mismatched mugs in the cupboard above my sink give a glimpse of sentimentality that is largely missing from the rest of my home.

In general, women’s decisions are rarely portrayed as acts of free will at all.

While these are relatively unconscious and frivolous externalizations of my personality, my bookshelf was always a carefully curated, purposeful manifestation of my deepest self and fundamental desires. Before I unceremoniously sold all my books and moved to another country, I would obsessively sort through the shelves, deciding which books should sit at eye level, what each one said about me, and which ones best encapsulated my view of this complicated world. My obsession with arranging my own bookshelf made it impossible for me to stop myself from scanning for clues on others’ shelves.

This particular ex-boyfriend had a stack of boating magazines on his top shelf, and he’d placed Margaret Atwood, Ray Bradbury, and Philip K. Dick at eye level. This assortment made me wonder if he’d ever read Octavia E. Butler, and I made a mental note to ask him about it. Earlier in the week, he’d told me he wanted to be a stay-at-home dad, so I looked at the books on his bottom shelf and wondered if one day he’d read his Calvin and Hobbes comics and Pippi Longstocking books to his child. The manual for his stove sat horizontally on the top shelf, and his English degree lay limply over top of it.

To be honest, I can’t remember a lot about this man, but I remember his bookshelf clearly. It stirred up in me all the questions and inquisitiveness I’d been trying to get my own bookshelf to bring about in others. While I scanned the shelves, I replayed all the times the men I’ve dated have nodded at my bookshelf and said, “ya, that makes sense.” While it’s never said with disdain or dismissal, it seems that no matter how I arrange my bookshelf or what I put on it, it always validates preformed predictions. Even when my interests are genuinely admired and given ample attention, they’re still treated like a series of unchangeable inevitabilities.

While admiring my collection of Hemingway short stories, a man once said, “Ah, of course you fell for a badass like that.” While I am repulsed by the idea that someone would assume I select reading material based on my physical attraction to the author, the idea that some uncontrollable force drew me to a particular interest is more troublesome to me. Behind every admiring remark about my interests, there seems to be an assumption that I simply “fell” into them.

My propensity to read my horoscope has always been met with a uniquely adamant and frantic assumption that I must have been unconsciously attracted to it. The men I’ve dated usually physically move away from me, and they often can’t think of a way to move the conversation forward after I’ve mentioned my star sign (and they nearly shut down if I mention my moon sign). While I can maybe understand their initial skepticism and surprise, it bothers me that almost none of them inquire about the reasoning behind my interest in astrology. It’s as though they don’t consider it something I decided at all. I mean, how could the otherwise intelligent and savvy woman in front of them believe in something as silly and ridiculous as star alignment?

In general, women’s decisions are rarely portrayed as acts of free will. More often, they are considered predetermined by their bodies. My ex-boyfriend’s eventual decision to be a stay-at-home dad and read his child Pippi Longstocking might be unfairly viewed by some as an “unmanly” choice, and while he might face harmful backlash for it, at least it will be considered his own decision. But if I were to make the same choice, it likely wouldn’t be considered a decision at all. A woman’s desire to have children and/or to care for them isn’t really viewed as an active choice or a result of societal pressures. More often, it’s seen as an overwhelming biological urge that comes from deep within her body and cannot be quelled. Similarly, if my ex-boyfriend decided to work instead of staying home with his child, it wouldn’t be seen as a diversion from his body’s natural impulses like it would if I decided to work. At its core, the decision to carry or care for another human being is not seen as my own but rather my body’s.

Men’s bodies are rarely considered to be the cause of anything. Instead, we see external circumstances as impacting their decisions.

My decision to major in English and pursue a career in art is often met with boredom and shrugs, whereas my history in prototyping technologies is met with confusion. It’s assumed that I chose the humanities and art not because of my unique abilities with words or drawing but because my brain is physically wired for artistic, emotional work. Intelligent articles about women in science or technology are met with links to articles that claim women’s brains are not built to take on mathematical or spatial work. I can guarantee it was rarely suggested that my ex-boyfriend’s brain was physically unprepared to understand complex emotional subtext in contemporary fiction. My brain, however, appears to be destined for it.

I would never suggest that men do not face criticism for choosing certain kinds of work or interests. I’ve seen men torn apart by their fathers or rude acquaintances who suggest they’ve made silly choices or that their social circumstances must have led them down such a ridiculous path when they could have been doctors or architects. No one, however, suggests that the male brain or body is physically incapable of pursuing any interest or decision. Men’s bodies are rarely considered to be the cause of anything. Instead, it is external circumstances that impact their decisions.

While blaming or crediting societal circumstances for a person’s well-considered decisions isn’t always great, at least it’s somewhat escapable. If I wanted to escape assumptions about my decisions and interests, it appears I would have to physically crawl out of my own body.

This unconscious (and occasionally conscious) treatment of my body as some sort of prophetic machine honestly sounds more ludicrous than astrology’s predictions. Astrology is no less ridiculous or scientifically inaccurate than the idea that the female body somehow determines future decisions, reactions, and interests. Yet we seem to perpetuate this latter idea without hesitation.

We’re all navigating the world looking for clues about who we are, who the people in our lives are, and how our lives are going to turn out. I believe that reading horoscopes and comparing astrological charts is a healthier way to make sense of the world than building false stereotypes and treating people like unconscious agents in their own lives.

I don’t believe in astrology the way I wish I did. I don’t believe the sun determines my personality or the planets determine my mood. I wish I was that witchy, and I will continue to be in awe of people who are. After scrolling through thousands of articles that subtly or directly suggest that my body’s physical structure determines how I exist in the world, however, I find the deepest level of joy and comfort in subscribing to the idea that it’s actually the universe’s physical alignment that affects how I exist in the world. According to astrology, my decisions, interests, and reactions are directly affected by external circumstances. It doesn’t matter what body I inhabit. If it’s Pisces season and I’m born at the end of February, I’m going to be intolerably moody, intuitive, and cry a lot.

I love astrological explanations of my personality. I love comparing my chart to the people around me. My horoscope acts as a daily reminder that despite everything in society telling me otherwise, the world and the people in it do affect me. In a subtle and mythical but wildly important way, astrology reminds me I exist.
